Inference: High water usage cycles followed by strong soil moisture increases indicate effective irrigation delivery
Description: If soil moisture rises noticeably after high-volume watering cycles, the irrigation system is successfully transferring water into the soil profile.
short rationale: Irrigation effectiveness only; operational efficiency with low privacy risk.

Inference: High water usage cycles followed by weak soil moisture response indicate poor soil absorption or runoff
Description: Large irrigation volumes that produce only small moisture increases suggest hydrophobic soil, compaction, or surface runoff.
short rationale: Weak absorption/runoff signal; operational issue, minimal privacy impact.

Inference: Low water usage cycles accompanied by stable or rising soil moisture indicate residual moisture retention
Description: When minimal irrigation still results in stable or increasing moisture, soil retains water well or previous irrigation left adequate reserves.
short rationale: Shows retention with low watering; mild operational context.

Inference: Low water usage cycles followed by rapid soil moisture decline indicate insufficient watering
Description: If soil dries quickly after small-volume cycles, irrigation volumes are too low to sustain moisture levels.
short rationale: Indicates watering volume too low; limited privacy exposure.

Inference: Increasing irrigation volume across cycles with no corresponding rise in soil moisture suggests irrigation inefficiency
Description: Growing water usage without moisture improvements may signal leaks, clogged emitters, or poor infiltration.
short rationale: Reveals inefficiency or leaks across cycles; operational/maintenance exposure.

Inference: Decreasing irrigation volume with stable soil moisture indicates efficient watering or improved soil water-holding capacity
Description: Reductions in water use without moisture decline suggest higher efficiency or environmental moisture retention.
short rationale: Reduced watering while moisture holds steady; mild efficiency clue.

Inference: Consistent high soil moisture despite reduced water usage signals natural moisture contribution or decreasing demand
Description: If the system waters less but moisture stays high, soil or environmental conditions are retaining water effectively.
short rationale: Natural retention lowers demand; operational context with low risk.

Inference: Consistent low soil moisture despite increased water usage suggests chronic under-watering or poor retention
Description: Increasing irrigation fails to raise moisture, likely due to drainage, sandy soils, or insufficient cycle duration.
short rationale: Chronic low moisture despite more water flags system/retention limits; operational exposure.

Inference: High-frequency watering cycles with only modest soil moisture effects indicate rapid soil drying environment
Description: If frequent irrigation barely elevates moisture, the soil loses water rapidly through evaporation or drainage.
short rationale: High-frequency schedule with weak effect reveals watering behavior and site stress.

Inference: High-frequency watering cycles with large moisture spikes suggest aggressive but effective replenishment
Description: Large, repeated increases imply the system delivers frequent substantial hydration.
short rationale: Aggressive frequent watering pattern exposed; operational/behavioral insight.

Inference: Water usage spikes that occur only when soil moisture reaches low thresholds indicate moisture-dependent irrigation
Description: The system responds to low moisture values with higher-volume cycles, implying threshold-triggered watering.
short rationale: Threshold-triggered watering logic disclosed; shows control behavior.

Inference: Water usage reductions that occur when soil moisture remains high indicate proper water-saving behavior
Description: If the system lowers irrigation volumes when moisture is elevated, watering logic matches soil conditions.
short rationale: Adaptive water-saving when moisture is high; mild operational behavior signal.

Inference: No change in water usage despite large swings in soil moisture suggests static irrigation rules
Description: If watering volumes stay constant regardless of moisture changes, the irrigation is not adaptive.
short rationale: Static watering despite moisture swings reveals configuration/oversight.

Inference: Large soil moisture increases following smaller-than-usual watering cycles indicate highly efficient soil conditions
Description: When less water delivers strong hydration results, soil is absorbing and retaining water effectively.
short rationale: Efficient soil response to smaller cycles; operational efficiency note.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing at high levels while water usage trends downward suggests optimized irrigation strategy
Description: Steady moisture with decreasing water use indicates fine-tuned efficiency and good soil conditions.
short rationale: High moisture with shrinking use implies optimization; low privacy exposure.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing at low levels despite high water usage suggests water delivery constraints
Description: If moisture stays low regardless of heavy watering, irrigation reach or pressure may be inadequate.
short rationale: Persistent low moisture despite heavy watering signals delivery constraint; operational exposure.

Inference: Rapid soil moisture fluctuations with stable water usage indicate environmental or soil variability rather than irrigation-driven effects
Description: When moisture changes significantly despite uniform watering, external factors drive moisture dynamics.
short rationale: Moisture swings driven by environment with steady watering; minimal privacy impact.

Inference: Stable soil moisture with highly variable water usage suggests over-responsive or unstable irrigation logic
Description: Large changes in watering volumes that do not affect moisture levels indicate excessive system adjustments.
short rationale: Variable watering without moisture change shows unstable control behavior.

Inference: Soil moisture spikes immediately after a single large water cycle identify cycle-specific over-watering risk
Description: One heavy cycle creating a large jump may indicate cycles are occasionally over-delivering water.
short rationale: Single heavy cycle causing spike exposes over-watering event/behavior.

Inference: Gradual soil moisture rise over many small water cycles indicates cumulative rehydration strategy
Description: Small but repeated volumes build up moisture slowly and safely.
short rationale: Cumulative small-cycle strategy noted; mild schedule exposure.

Inference: Sharp moisture decline following low water usage cycles indicates high evapotranspiration or dry conditions
Description: If moisture drops rapidly after light watering, environmental demand exceeds what the system provides.
short rationale: Environmental demand signal only; no behavioral detail.

Inference: Absence of soil moisture rise after any water usage increase suggests sensor misalignment or malfunction
Description: If added water never changes measured moisture, the sensor may not reflect hydrated zones.
short rationale: Sensor/placement fault implied; maintenance/operational exposure.

Inference: Excessive soil moisture following only modest water usage cycles indicates high soil saturation or poor drainage
Description: Small irrigation volumes producing high moisture spikes imply limited drainage capacity.
short rationale: Saturation/drainage limit insight; low privacy impact.

Inference: Increasing water usage correlating with increasingly small moisture gains indicates diminishing irrigation efficiency
Description: More water produces less impact each cycle, suggesting soil saturation or structural water flow limitations.
short rationale: Diminishing returns with more water expose inefficiency or leaks; operational exposure.

Inference: Decreasing water usage correlating with stable or rising soil moisture indicates improvements in soil structure or conditions
Description: Enhanced absorption or reduced loss allows less water to maintain moisture levels.
short rationale: Soil improvement allows less water; mild operational detail.

Inference: Water usage consistency paired with cumulative increase in soil moisture indicates overwatering trend
Description: If cycles use the same volumes but moisture trends upward over time, hydration exceeds losses.
short rationale: Overwatering trend with steady volumes reveals watering routine/behavior.

Inference: Water usage consistency paired with cumulative decrease in soil moisture indicates under-watering trend
Description: Stable watering volumes are insufficient to maintain soil moisture across cycles.
short rationale: Under-watering trend from fixed volumes shows operational oversight.

Inference: Large moisture drops without reduction in water usage indicate increased environmental demand
Description: If moisture falls sharply despite typical watering, external drying forces are rising.
short rationale: Rising environmental demand despite steady watering; minimal privacy risk.

Inference: High water usage cycles with identical moisture outcomes across zones indicate uniform soil characteristics
Description: Same water volume produces similar moisture response in different areas, implying soil homogeneity.
short rationale: Uniform response across zones; site context only, low risk.

Inference: Different moisture outcomes from identical watering cycles reveal heterogeneous soil conditions
Description: Uniform irrigation produces varying moisture outcomes indicating diverse retention and infiltration properties.
short rationale: Heterogeneous soil/retention pattern; site profiling with low privacy impact.
